page.title: 05ECOLOGY
page.content: With a long coastline, few trees or hedges, and dyke-edged sheep pasture and arable, Camber's breeding birds are somewhat restricted, ranging from redshank, ringed plover and oystercatcher to wheatear, yellow wagtail and corn bunting. The once famous Midrips has now only one stretch of water but still mamanges to attract a few scarce waders on migration, while other migrants passing through the area include firecrest, black redstart and the occasional hoopoe or golden oriole. In winter hen harriers and short-eared owls range over the fields. Camber is a happy hunting ground for lepidopterists, with sand dart, nutmeg and lyme grass among the rarities. For botanists the littoral has a good range of coastal plants, such as seakale, sea holly and sea pea.
